text: Trees communicate through an underground fungal network called the 'Wood Wide Web,' sharing nutrients and warnings.
The largest organism on Earth is a honey fungus in Oregon spanning 2,385 acres — about 1,665 football fields.
Bamboo is the fastest-growing plant, capable of growing 35 inches in a single day.
Venus flytraps can count — they only close when triggered twice within 20 seconds to avoid false alarms.
Some mushrooms create their own wind by releasing water vapor to spread their spores.
The corpse flower smells like rotting flesh to attract pollinators and only blooms once every 7-10 years.
Caffeine is a natural pesticide that plants produce to poison insects.
Oak trees don't produce acorns until they're at least 20 years old.
The oldest known tree is over 5,000 years old — a bristlecone pine named Methuselah in California.
Fungi are more closely related to animals than to plants.
Pando is a clonal colony of quaking aspens in Utah that's technically one organism weighing 6,000 metric tons.
Grass appeared only about 55 million years ago — it's a relatively recent plant.
Some plants have developed a taste for meat — there are over 600 species of carnivorous plants.
The smell of freshly cut grass is actually a plant distress signal — a chemical cry for help.
Mycelium networks can extend for miles and can transfer nutrients between trees of different species.
Penicillin was accidentally discovered from the Penicillium mold growing on a petri dish.
Sunflowers track the sun across the sky (heliotropism) when young, but face east when mature.
The world's smallest flowering plant, Wolffia, is the size of a grain of salt.
Trees release chemicals called phytoncides that reduce stress hormones when humans breathe them.
Avocados evolved to be eaten by giant ground sloths — now extinct, so humans have taken over seed dispersal.
A single mature oak tree can produce 10,000 acorns in a year.
Lightning helps plants grow by fixing nitrogen in the air into a form plants can use.
Mushrooms are only the 'fruit' of fungi — most of the organism lives underground as mycelium.
Some seeds require fire to germinate — certain pine cones only open after being heated by forest fires.
The sandbox tree has explosive seed pods that shoot seeds at 160 mph.
Psilocybin mushrooms may have influenced human evolution and the development of language.
Trees can 'talk' to each other through chemicals released into the air when attacked by insects.
The titan arum has the largest unbranched flower structure in the world — up to 10 feet tall.
Cordyceps fungi turn ants into 'zombies,' controlling their behavior to spread spores.
The baobab tree can store up to 32,000 gallons of water in its trunk.
Dandelions aren't weeds in many countries — they're eaten as salad greens.
The manchineel tree is so toxic that standing under it during rain can cause blisters.
Moss can survive complete desiccation and come back to life after decades.
The resurrection plant can survive losing 95% of its water content and revive within hours of watering.
Truffle-hunting pigs are being replaced by dogs because pigs eat the truffles they find.
Bananas are radioactive due to their potassium content, but you'd need to eat millions to be harmed.
Trees don't die of old age — they're killed by disease, insects, or environmental stress.
The gympie-gympie plant from Australia has a sting so painful it's driven people to suicide.
Seaweed produces about 70% of the world's oxygen.
Some orchids have evolved to look exactly like female wasps to attract male wasps for pollination.
The welwitschia plant can live 2,000 years and only ever grows two leaves.
Fungi were the first organisms to colonize land, paving the way for plants.
Pine trees can be used as compasses — their branches tend to be fuller on the sunny side.
The oldest seed ever germinated was from a Judean date palm and was about 2,000 years old.
Tomatoes, peppers, and eggplants are all members of the deadly nightshade family.
Yeast, used for bread and beer, is a single-celled fungus.
Some trees can move — the walking palm 'walks' by growing new roots and letting old ones die.
The Amazon rainforest produces about 20% of the world's oxygen and is called 'the lungs of the Earth.'
Lichen are actually two organisms living together — a fungus and an alga or cyanobacterium.
Cannabis and hops (used in beer) are botanical cousins in the same plant family.
